revised_title: Reestablishing Scientific Connections and Collaboration Post-WWII
tldr: In 1946, the Royal Society appointed a committee to reestablish contact with foreign academies and learned societies after World War II. Representatives visited Denmark, Norway, Czechoslovakia, Belgium, Holland, and France to convey greetings and explore ways the Royal Society could assist in the rehabilitation of science in those countries. The visits aimed to foster international collaboration, exchange information, and provide support for scientific institutions that had suffered during the war. The countries expressed their needs, including access to scientific literature, journals, and opportunities for exchange programs and research abroad.
